comments:
This is a continuation of BIOL 101 or 121 focusing on structure and function of animals, with emphasis on the principles of physiology, development, ecology and the diversity of adaptations. 

One student said it was a “very interesting” course. It was “much more intellectually stimulating than Biology 101,” with “useful content that every human being should know.” Students found the audio recordings “invaluable.”

There were overwhelmingly unfavorable reviews of Dr. Dunham. One student noted: “If I had known that Dr. Dunham was going to read off of the slides for half of a semester and then administer the same 3rd midterm and final that he did the previous year, I would have gone to a community college for a better experience.” Another said Dr. Dunham “seemed unprepared and did very little to stimulate student interest.” Yet another student felt that Dr. Dunham “did not appear to be passionate about what he was teaching and glossed over many details too quickly. His style of teaching made it difficult to pay attention.”

Students felt “the exams are made difficult to understand and, in lab, points are taken off for the most minor and easy to overlook things just to get a bell-curve distribution.” They were shocked to find the third exam to be identical to the practice test distributed to the class. One student noted that “it is fairly easy if you have taken AP Bio.” Another felt “the amount of material at times is extremely daunting, but if the proper time is put forth then it is possible to get a good grade,” provided students do not get behind on the material. One complaint was that readings and lectures did not regularly match up. Students should expect to spend at least an hour a day on the course.

This is a continuation of BIOL 101 or 121 focusing on structure and function of animals, with emphasis on the principles of physiology, development, ecology and the diversity of adaptations. 

One student said it was a “very interesting” course. It was “much more intellectually stimulating than Biology 101,” with “useful content that every human being should know.” Students found the audio recordings “invaluable.” 

Professor Helliker was “a great, interesting lecturer.” He was “friendly and got students interested in even some of the less stimulating material.”

Students felt “the exams are made difficult to understand and, in lab, points are taken off for the most minor and easy to overlook things just to get a bell-curve distribution.” They were shocked to find the third exam to be identical to the practice test distributed to the class. One student noted that “it is fairly easy if you have taken AP Bio.” Another felt “the amount of material at times is extremely daunting, but if the proper time is put forth then it is possible to get a good grade,” provided students do not get behind on the material. One complaint was that readings and lectures did not regularly match up. Students should expect to spend at least an hour a day on the course.

This course covers general principles of biology focusing on structure and function of animals, with emphasis on the principles of physiology, development, evolution, ecology, and the diversity of adaptations.

Students found the course to be "interesting for medical students” but also more practical for other students. One student felt "very prepared for the MCAT and for upper level classes."

Dr. Witmer "really cared about how her students perform academically." Students found her to be "incredibly knowledgeable," and used words such as "dedicated” and “amazing” to describe her. One student commented that her lectures were “superficial” since the material was not discussed in depth; however, the general consensus was that Dr. Witmer “delivered [course material] effectively through instructor slide shows, assigned readings and problems.”

Some students found that exam questions were based on "how well the student understands Witmer's intentions in writing the question" rather than knowledge of the material, making the exams difficult. Also, although the lectures are recorded, they are not made available, even if students miss a lecture with prior notice.
